revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=May 2018}} {{Infobox company | name = MoviePass, Inc. | logo = MoviePass.png | type = [[Privately held company|Private]] | industry = [[Entertainment]] | founded = {{Start date and age|2011}} in [[New York City]], [[New York (state)|New York]], U.S. | founders = [[Stacy Spikes]]
Hamet Watt | location_city = [[New York City]], [[New York (state)|New York]] | location_country = [[United States]] | area_served = United States | key_people = [[Mitch Lowe]] ([[Chief executive officer|CEO]]) | products = | services = Subscription-based movie ticketing | revenue = | operating_income = | net_income = | assets = | equity = | owner = [[#Helios and Matheson Analytics|Helios and Matheson Analytics]] (Majority)
[[Oath Inc.]] | num_employees = | parent = | divisions = | subsid = [[MoviePass Films]]
MoviePass Ventures | website = {{URL|www.moviepass.com}} | footnotes = }} '''MoviePass, Inc.''' is an American [[subscription]]-based movie ticketing service{{cite news |last1=McArdle |first1=Megan |title=Three theories on why MoviePass failed |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/opinions/three-theories-on-why-moviepass-failed/2018/08/02/a39ccc36-9691-11e8-80e1-00e80e1fdf43_story.html?utm_term=.765092109d10 |accessdate=3 August 2018 |publisher=Washington Post |date=2 August 2018}} majority owned by Helios and Matheson Analytics. Founded in 2011 and headquartered in [[New York City]],{{cite web|url=https://venturebeat.com/2012/10/02/moviepass-theater-subscription-service/|title=MoviePass debuts an unlimited movie service that may just save cinemas|date=October 2, 2012|website=VentureBeat|access-date=August 16, 2017}} the service allows subscribers to purchase up to three movie tickets per month for a monthly fee. {{Cite news|url=https://www.engadget.com/2018/08/24/moviepass-annual-subscribers-three-movie-plan/|title=MoviePass forces annual subscribers to its new three-movie plan early|work=Engadget|access-date=2018-08-25|language=en-US}} The service utilizes a [[mobile app]], where users [[Check-in#Social network|check-into]] a cinema and choose a film and showtime, which results in the cost of the ticket being loaded to a prepaid debit card, which is used to purchase the ticket from the cinema as usual. The service went through several pricing structures following its original invite-only launch (including those limited to 2 or 3 films per month, and "unlimited" plans, with pricing based on market size), before announcing in August 2017 that it would switch to offering a plan with a single film per day priced at $9.95 per month.{{Cite news|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/how-moviepass-works-2017-8|title=Here's how to use MoviePass, the $10-a-month service that lets you see one movie per day in theaters|work=Business Insider|access-date=August 17, 2017|language=en}} The change in business model came with the acquisition of a majority stake in the company by an analytics firm, which sought to widen the service's reach so it could collect more information on customer viewing habits. MoviePass was named as one of the "25 Most Disruptive Apps of 2012" and part of "The Best of Everything in 2012" by ''[[Business Insider]]''.{{cite web|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/the-top-25-most-disruptive-apps-2012-12|title=The Top 25 Most Disruptive Apps Of 2012 - Business Insider|date=December 7, 2012|work=Business Insider|accessdate=October 11, 2014}}{{cite web|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/the-best-of-everything-in-2012-2012-12#best-entertainment-app-moviepass-4|title=The Best Of Everything In 2012|date=December 24, 2012|work=Business Insider|accessdate=October 11, 2014}} The 2017 change in business model has been successful in attracting customers; the service reported having 2 million subscribers in February 2018. That same month, the company announced at the [[Sundance Film Festival]] that it would also acquire and distribute films under the new subsidiary, MoviePass Ventures. Since its launch, MoviePass has faced objections from major cinema chains, particularly [[AMC Theatres]], over its business model and sustainability. These concerns were exacerbated in July 2018, when the service was forced to temporarily shut down for a day in order to negotiate an additional loan, and began to make other changes such as reducing its unlimited plan to only offer 3 no-cost tickets per-month (with further tickets only being discounted), implementing [[dynamic pricing|demand-based]] fees and blackouts on specific high-profile releases, and ultimately restricting the service to a limited selection of up to six specified films, rotating daily. ==History== ===2011–2015=== MoviePass was founded in 2011{{Cite news|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-08-15/netflix-co-founder-s-crazy-plan-pay-10-a-month-go-to-the-movies-all-you-want|title=Netflix Co-Founder’s Crazy Plan: Pay $10 a Month, Go to the Movies All You Want|date=August 15, 2017|work=Bloomberg.com|access-date=August 16, 2017}} by technology and entertainment entrepreneurs [[Stacy Spikes]] and Hamet Watt.{{citation needed|date=June 2018}} It is backed by major investors including True Ventures, AOL Ventures, Lambert Media, Moxie Pictures and other investors.{{Cite news|url=http://deadline.com/2011/06/moviepass-trying-to-go-forward-with-test-weekend-despite-nix-by-two-movie-chains-144755/|title=UPDATE: MoviePass Gets Its Ticket Punched As Trial Launch Is Cancelled After Two Movie Chains Give It Thumbs Down|last=Jr|first=Mike Fleming|date=July 1, 2011|website=Deadline Hollywood|access-date=August 16, 2017|language=en-US}} The company launched in beta in June 2011 in [[San Francisco]]. During initial trials, it encountered resistance from movie theater chains, resulting in the company going on a "temporary hiatus". At first, MoviePass operated with a voucher system. Members printed a voucher on their home computers and redeemed them for movie tickets at participating cinemas. In August 2011, the company partnered with Hollywood Movie Money to conduct its service through its preexisting voucher program and cinema network.{{Cite news|url=http://www.thewrap.com/moviepass-tries-unlimted-movie-plan-again-time-help-30561/|title=MoviePass Tries Unlimited Movie Plan Again, This Time With Help|date=August 30, 2011|work=TheWrap|access-date=August 16, 2017|language=en-US}} The voucher system was replaced after users complained it was cumbersome. In October 2012, following a national [[beta test]], the service switched to a mobile app and electronically-preloaded prepaid card. While MoviePass claimed the card could be used at all cinemas that accepted major credit cards, there was still some hostility from the industry, including [[AMC Theatres]], who publicly disassociated itself from the service.{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/01/20/nyregion/a-movie-a-day-without-breaking-the-bank.html|title=A Movie a Day, Without Breaking the Bank|last=Brustein|first=Joshua|date=January 18, 2013|work=The New York Times|access-date=August 16, 2017|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}}{{Cite news|url=http://business.time.com/2012/10/02/moviepass-goes-national-unlimited-trips-to-the-movies-from-25-per-month/|title=MoviePass Goes National: Unlimited Trips to the Movies from $25 Per Month|last=Tuttle|first=Brad|work=Time|access-date=August 16, 2017|language=en-US|issn=0040-781X}} ===2016=== In June 2016, MoviePass named [[Mitch Lowe]], a former executive of [[Netflix]] and [[Redbox]], as its new CEO. Lowe had been an advisor to the company since 2014.{{cite web|title=Ex-Netflix Exec Mitch Lowe Takes Over as MoviePass CEO|url=https://variety.com/2016/digital/exec-shuffle-people-news/mitch-lowe-moviepass-ceo-1201805026/|website=Variety|accessdate=October 27, 2017}} Under Lowe, the service began to experiment with different pricing models; Lowe stated that his eventual goal was to have a low-end service at around $20 per month, ranging up towards a high-end service at around $100 with unlimited movies and availability of 3D screenings. In some regions, the service tried offering different subscription plans to users, such as a $50 plan for six movies per month, or $99 for unlimited—both allowing users to purchase tickets to 3D screenings. The new plans were criticized by those who felt that they were designed to [[price gouging|gouge]] "unprofitable" frequent users of the service.{{cite web|last1=Lang|first1=Brett|title=MoviePass to Experiment With New Pricing Models, CEO Says|url=https://variety.com/2016/film/news/moviepass-new-prices-netflix-mitch-lowe-1201806341/|website=Variety|accessdate=August 17, 2017|quote="What they’re trying to do is eliminate the unprofitable people. The people who use the service all the time."}} In July 2016, MoviePass unveiled a new plan structure effective in September, with tiers based on 2, 3 or unlimited movies per month. Prices varied by region, with (for example) the two-movie-per-month plan costing from $15 in small markets to $21 in larger ones. The unlimited plans were also modified to remove the previous restriction of one film every 24 hours, with prices ranging from $40 to $50 per month. Lowe argued that the new plans were designed to appeal to those who did not go to movies often.{{cite web|url=https://www.engadget.com/2016/07/12/moviepass-unveils-new-prices-starting-at-15-a-month/|title=MoviePass unveils new prices, starting at $15 a month|last=devindra|website=Engadget|access-date=October 21, 2016}} In December 2016, the service had 20,000 subscribers.{{Cite news|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/moviepass-get-serious-customer-acquisition-957690|title=MoviePass Gets Serious About Customer Acquisition|work=The Hollywood Reporter|access-date=November 6, 2017|language=en}} Studio Movie Grill purchased a stake in the company in December 2016. MoviePass and Studio Movie Grill were also partnering on testing food features through the MoviePass app including [[OpenTable]] (purchases) and Explore More (menu).{{cite news |last1=Verhoeven |first1=Beatrice |title=MoviePass Launches Partnership with Studio Movie Grill |url=https://www.thewrap.com/moviepass-studio-movie-grill-partnership/ |accessdate=June 4, 2018 |work=TheWrap |date=December 19, 2016}} ===2017-2018=== In August 2017, a majority stake in MoviePass was sold to the analytics firm Helios and Matheson. At the same time, the company announced that it would lower its price for an unlimited plan allowing one film per-day, to $9.95 per month. Lowe explained that "after years of studying and analysis we found that people want to go to the movies more often, but the pricing keeps going up, and that prevents them from going more. We're making it more affordable for people." Helios and Matheson's CEO Ted Farnsworth stated the service wanted to increase the size of its userbase in order to analyze viewing habits for [[targeted advertising]]. Farnsworth compared the model to those of [[Facebook]] and [[Google]], whose free services are subsidized by the collection of personal information for advertising.{{Cite news|url=https://variety.com/2017/film/news/moviepass-1202527956/|title=MoviePass Sells to Helios and Matheson Analytics|last=Lang|first=Brent|date=August 15, 2017|work=Variety|access-date=August 16, 2017|language=en-US}} After announcing their new pricing, the company's website went down due to the increase in traffic.{{Cite news|url=https://www.inverse.com/article/35561-moviepass-site-down-traffic-subscription-deal|title=MoviePass's Crazy Popular Subscription Deal Immediately Crashed the Site|work=Inverse|access-date=August 17, 2017|language=en}} By September 2017, the number of subscribers had increased to 400,000, to 600,000 in mid-October, to one million in December, and two million in February 2018. In June 2018, the company announced in a press release that it had more than three million paying subscribers. {{cite news | url=http://www.businessinsider.com/moviepass-struggling-to-keep-up-as-subscriptions-surged-to-400000-2017-9 | title=After cutting prices for its movie-a-day subscription service, MoviePass is struggling to keep up with demand | first=Caroline | last=Cakebread | work=[[Business Insider]] | date=September 14, 2017 | accessdate=September 21, 2017}}{{cite news | url=http://www.marketwatch.com/story/moviepass-is-now-servicing-more-than-600000-subscribers-2017-10-24 | first=Trey | last=Williams | title=MoviePass is now servicing more than 600,000 subscribers | work=[[MarketWatch]] | date=October 24, 2017 | accessdate=October 27, 2017}}{{Cite news|url=https://variety.com/2018/film/box-office/moviepass-2-million-mark-subscribers-1202692553/|title=MoviePass Tops 2 Million Mark in Subscribers|last=McNary|first=Dave|date=February 8, 2017|work=Variety|access-date=March 9, 2018|language=en-US}} Helios advanced MoviePass $55 million from December to February 20, 2018. MoviePass then converted the advances from debt to capital. Helios ownership stake thus increased from 62.4 percent to 81.2 percent. Another $35 million in advances converted to capital put Helios to 91.8 percent allowing for a merger unilateral initiated by the Helios board.{{cite news |last1=Morgan |first1=Richard |title=MoviePass owners weighing merger despite burning through cash |url=https://nypost.com/2018/04/22/moviepass-owners-weighing-merger-despite-burning-through-cash/ |accessdate=June 5, 2018 |work=New York Post |date=April 23, 2018}} On January 19, 2018 at the [[Sundance Film Festival]], MoviePass announced the new subsidiary MoviePass Ventures, which would co-acquire films with traditional distributors.{{Cite news|url=https://variety.com/2018/film/news/moviepass-sundance-1202669456/|title=Sundance: MoviePass Announces It Will Acquire Films|last=Lang|first=Brent|date=January 19, 2018|work=Variety|access-date=January 19, 2018|language=en-US}}{{Cite news|url=http://deadline.com/2018/01/moviepass-film-finance-moviepass-ventures-sundance-film-festival-1202262786/|title=MoviePass Launches MoviePass Ventures: Subsidiary Will Co-Acquire Films With Distributors – Sundance|last=D'Alessandro|first=Anthony|date=January 19, 2018|website=Deadline Hollywood|access-date=January 19, 2018|language=en-US}} In February 2018, the price further dropped to $7.95 per month for new customers if they paid annually.{{Cite news|url=https://mashable.com/2018/02/10/movie-pass-price-drop/#TaAtQLdbHkqh|title=MoviePass lowered it's prices again, somehow|last=Allen Clark|first=Peter|date=February 10, 2018|work=[[Mashable]]|access-date=February 10, 2018}} In March, they lowered it to $6.95.{{cite news |title=Moviepass Lowers Price To $6.95 Per Month |url=https://www.reuters.com/finance/stocks/HMNY.OQ/key-developments/article/3792478 |accessdate=June 5, 2018 |work=Reuters |date=March 23, 2018 |language=en}} In April 2018, Helios and Matheson acquired the movie listings website [[Moviefone]] from [[Verizon Communications]]'s digital media subsidiary [[Oath Inc.]], with Verizon taking a stake in MoviePass stock.{{Cite news|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2018-04-05/moviepass-teams-with-moviefone-to-shake-up-theater-business|title=MoviePass Acquires Moviefone to Bolster Film-a-Day Service|last=Smith|first=Gerry|date=April 5, 2018|work=[[Bloomberg News|Bloomberg]]|access-date=April 5, 2018}}{{Cite news|url=http://fortune.com/2018/04/05/moviepass-buys-moviefone/|title=MoviePass Just Bought Moviefone. Here's What It Means for Moviegoers|work=Fortune|access-date=April 6, 2018|language=en}} Also in April 2018, MoviePass quietly removed the unlimited plan for new customers, and replaced it with a new plan limited to three movies per-month, bundled with a complimentary three-month trial of [[iHeartRadio]] All-Access. Lowe stated that he was not sure if the previous plan would be reinstated, explaining that "We just always try different things. Every time we try a new promotion, we never put a deadline on it."{{cite web|url=https://techcrunch.com/2018/04/26/moviepass-ceo-one-movie-per-day/|title=MoviePass CEO says he doesn’t know if the one-movie-per-day subscription will ever return|website=TechCrunch|language=en-US|access-date=April 26, 2018}} There was also a change that prohibited MoviePass customers from buying multiple tickets to "select" movies.{{cite news |title="MoviePass Unlimited" |url=https://www.theverge.com/2018/4/27/17291242/moviepass-unlimited-movie-deal-repeat-viewings-theater-blackouts |work=Verge |date=April 27, 2018}} The unlimited plan was reinstated two weeks later, with the limited plan maintained as a cheaper option at the $7.95 price point; Lowe stated that the company was "absolutely committed" to keeping the unlimited option.{{cite web|last1=Barret|first1=Brian|title=MoviePass Revives Its Unlimited Plan|url=https://www.wired.com/story/movie-pass-unlimited-is-back/|website=Wired.com|accessdate=May 3, 2018}}{{subscription required}}{{cite news |last1=Goldsmith |first1=Jill |title=MoviePass Expands And Will Now Make Movies Too |url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/jillgoldsmith/2018/05/31/moviepass-expands-and-will-now-make-movies-too/#6ad2f71d400a |work=Forbes |date=May 31, 2018}} ==== Financial issues ==== In May 2018, the company lost $40 million.[https://www.forbes.com/sites/jamos/2018/07/05/moviepass-worst-month-ever-at-least-for-now/#6ac9e24877f5 "MoviePass' Worst Month Ever (At Least For Now)"], ''Forbes'', Jim Amos, July 5, 2018 In late June 2018, ''[[Forbes]]'' reported that MoviePass was responding to the creation of the competitor AMC Stubs A-List by announcing new fees for its service, with surge fees added to popular films and prime timeslots. The peak pricing rolled out was $2 to $6 extra during peak times. In the summer of 2018 the company launched a $164 million bond sale.[https://money.cnn.com/2018/07/05/media/moviepass-surge-pricing/index.html "MoviePass introduces surge pricing"], CNN, Jill Disis, July 5, 2018[https://variety.com/2018/film/news/moviepass-peak-pricing-surcharge-1202865767/ "MoviePass Launches ‘Peak Pricing’ Surcharge"], ''Variety'', Dave McNary, July 5, 2018 MoviePass said subscribers could waive one peak fee per month.[https://www.cnet.com/news/moviepass-surge-pricing-is-here-2-to-6-extra-at-peak-times/ "MoviePass surge pricing is here: $2 to $6 extra at peak times"], [[CNET]], Gordon Gottsegen, July 5, 2018 At the end of the month, MoviePass announced it would begin selling merchandise. On July 2, Helios and Matheson Analytics filed to raise $1.2 billion to keep MoviePass solvent. They filed to sell debt and securities.{{cite magazine|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/tonifitzgerald/2018/07/02/moviepass-may-survive-after-all-inside-its-new-bold-business-saving-plan/ |title=MoviePass May Survive After All: Inside Its Bold New Business-Saving Plan |publisher=Forbes.com |date= |accessdate=2018-10-23}} Following a "service interruption" on July 26, the firm announced that it was forced to borrow $5 million in order to continue its operations; auditors doubted whether the company would be able to remain in business.{{cite news |last1=Zaveri |first1=Mihir |title=Future of MoviePass Is in Doubt After Service Outage, Experts Say |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/07/29/business/moviepass-service-outage-finances.html |accessdate=July 30, 2018 |publisher=New York Times |date=July 29, 2018}} The weekend following this disruption, there were reports that screenings of ''[[Mission: Impossible – Fallout]]'' had been blacked out from the service.{{Cite news|url=https://deadline.com/2018/07/tom-cruise-moviepass-mission-impossible-fallout-movie-ticket-blackout-1202435040/|title=MoviePass ‘Impossible-Fallout’: Tom Cruise Pic Blocked On Ticket Service App Following Thursday Night Outage|last=D'Alessandro|first=Anthony|date=2018-07-27|work=Deadline|access-date=2018-07-31|language=en-US}} The following Monday, the company announced it would not be offering its services for upcoming major releases, such as ''[[The Meg]]'' (which was projected to debut to about $20 million), but would continue operating for smaller films, albeit with the continued peak pricing.{{Cite news|url=https://deadline.com/2018/07/moviepass-manic-monday-ticket-service-outage-again-at-major-chains-1202436719/|title=Is MoviePass Dead? Ticket Service Won’t Cover Big Pics Like ‘Meg’, ‘Christopher Robin’ In Near Future – Update |last=D'Alessandro|first=Anthony|date=July 30, 2018|work=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|access-date=July 31, 2018|language=en-US}} On August 6, 2018, MoviePass backtracked on plans to raise its monthly fee from $9.95 to $14.95,{{Cite news|url=https://www.vanityfair.com/hollywood/2018/07/moviepass-raising-prices|title=MoviePass Rises from the Dead After Raising Its Monthly Prices|last=Desta|first=Yohana|work=HWD|access-date=2018-08-02|language=en}} but announced that it would instead limit these subscribers to three free tickets per-month, with any further screening offering a $5 discount on the ticket price instead. MoviePass stated that this measure was intended to "protect the longevity of our company and prevent abuse of the service."{{Cite news|url=https://techcrunch.com/2018/08/06/moviepass-keeps-plan-at-10-but-limits-subscribers-to-three-movies-a-month/|title=MoviePass keeps plan at $10, but limits subscribers to three movies a month|work=TechCrunch|access-date=2018-08-06|language=en-US}} On August 16, 2018, MoviePass announced that it would also limit the service's film options to "up to six films to choose from daily, including a selection of major studio first-run films and independent releases".{{Cite news|url=https://techcrunch.com/2018/08/16/moviepass-is-limiting-selection-to-up-to-six-films-a-day/|title=MoviePass is limiting selection to ‘up to six films’ a day|work=TechCrunch|access-date=2018-08-17|language=en-US}} By early August 2018, Helios and Matheson completed the acquisition of Emmett Furla Oasis Films assets for the MoviePass subsidiary, [[MoviePass Films]].{{cite news |last1=Jr |first1=Mike Fleming |title=MoviePass Films Sets First Pic: Bruce Willis To Star In ’10 Minutes Gone’ |url=https://deadline.com/2018/08/moviepass-films-bruce-willis-10-minutes-gone-1202441596/ |accessdate=October 16, 2018 |work=Deadline |date=August 7, 2018}} On August 24, 2018, MoviePass announced that it had ceased providing its previous annual unlimited plan, with all subscribers transitioned to the monthly limited plan. Subscribers who do not wish to have this plan were instructed to cancel their subscriptions by August 31, 2018 to receive a pro-rated refund (as per the MoviePass terms of service, users who cancel their subscription may not re-join the service for 9 months).{{Cite news|url=https://www.cnet.com/news/moviepass-kills-off-its-annual-plan-even-if-you-already-paid-for-it/|title=MoviePass kills off its annual plan -- even if you already paid for it|date=2018-08-24|work=CNET|access-date=2018-08-25|language=en}} By October, reportedly over a million subscribers had cancelled the service.[https://seekingalpha.com/article/4223252-helios-matheson-cash-burn-slows-amid-significant-decline-moviepass-subscriptions Helios And Matheson: Cash Burn Slows Amid Significant Decline In MoviePass Subscriptions]. Seeking Alpha. 19 Nov 2018. ==Operation== Subscribers to MoviePass are issued a branded prepaid debit card. Using the MoviePass [[mobile app]], users check-in at a supported cinema, and select a film and showtime occurring within the next 30 minutes; the card is automatically loaded with the amount of money needed to purchase a single ticket from the cinema for that film. The user then purchases their ticket as usual, using their MoviePass card as their payment method.{{Cite news|url=http://appscout.pcmag.com/none/303448-moviepass-service-adds-funds-your-card-when-you-reach-the-theater|title=MoviePass Service Adds Funds Your Card When You Reach the Theater|work=PC Magazine|access-date=August 16, 2017|language=en}} Hence, the service is subsidizing the purchase of tickets directly from the cinema by the customer. Some cinemas support e-tickets through MoviePass.{{Cite news|url=https://variety.com/2017/film/news/moviepass-explainer-advantages-drawbacks-pros-cons-1202528720/|title=What Is MoviePass? The Pros and Cons of $10-a-Month Unlimited Films|last=Kelley|first=Seth|date=August 15, 2017|work=Variety|access-date=August 16, 2017|language=en-US}} MoviePass has said that its service is supported at 91% of U.S. cinemas. One regional dine-in chain, [[Studio Movie Grill]], made an investment in MoviePass, and partnered to pilot features such as food ordering from within the app.{{Cite news|url=https://thefilmstage.com/news/unlimited-with-certain-limits-moviepass-new-policy-brings-frustration/|title=Unlimited with Certain Limits, MoviePass’ New Policy Brings Frustration|date=January 17, 2017|work=The Film Stage|access-date=August 16, 2017|language=en-US}} The MoviePass service has several limitations. It cannot be used for screenings in specialty formats such as 3D or [[IMAX]]. The service also does not support advance purchase of tickets, and only allows solo purchases.{{cite web|url=https://www.engadget.com/2017/08/15/moviepass-unlimited-movies-10-dollars-a-month/|title=MoviePass’ $9.95 ‘unlimited’ deal is one movie a day|website=Engadget|access-date=August 16, 2017}}{{cite news|url=http://time.com/money/4903181/moviepass-subscription-questions/|title=Everything You Need to Know About MoviePass, the $10 Monthly Subscription for Unlimited Movie Tickets|last=Tuttle|first=Brad|website=Money|access-date=August 16, 2017}} Effective April 2018, a user may only use MoviePass on a particular film once.{{Cite news|url=https://www.engadget.com/2018/04/27/moviepass-no-movies-more-than-once/|title=MoviePass no longer lets you see the same movie more than once|work=Engadget|access-date=April 27, 2018|language=en-US}} As of July 2018, certain screenings [[Dynamic pricing|may have additional fees based on demand]].{{Cite news|url=https://variety.com/2018/film/news/moviepass-peak-pricing-surcharge-1202865767/|title=MoviePass Launches ‘Peak Pricing’ Surcharge|last=McNary|first=Dave|date=2018-07-05|work=Variety|access-date=2018-07-20|language=en-US}} ==Criticism and controversy== {{Anchor|Reception}} The business model of MoviePass has faced notable resistance from major cinema chains since its launch; the company's 21-theatre pilot in [[San Francisco]] was called off after objections by [[AMC Theatres]] and [[Landmark Theatres]], who were included in the slate of locations without their knowledge. Stacy Spikes explained to ''[[Deadline Hollywood]]'' that he "imagine[d] a day where studio executives can see real-time decisions that subscribers are making from their phones and devices. If studios say they are not interested in being able to talk to their customers, knowing what they are thinking and being able to notify them of things like ancillary items, and that theater owners aren't interested in having these people go to the movies more, and drive up concessions sales, and having us put all this in the palms of their hands, then I'm in the wrong business." Following the announcement of MoviePass's new pricing model in August 2017, AMC stated that it was "actively working now to determine whether it may be feasible to opt out and not participate in this shaky and unsustainable program", as "by definition and absent some other form of other compensation, MoviePass will be losing money on every subscriber seeing two movies or more in a month", and that lowering its prices in response to the service would harm the customer experience.{{Cite news|url=https://variety.com/2017/film/news/amc-moviepass-1202528974/|title=AMC Slams MoviePass, Threatening Legal Action|last=Lang|first=Brent|date=August 15, 2017|work=Variety|access-date=August 16, 2017|language=en-US}} The service's original pricing depended on a business model similar to those of [[health club]]s, where the company would profit more if customers paid for the service but only used it on occasion. ==Helios and Matheson Analytics== {{Infobox company | name = Helios and Matheson Analytics Inc. | logo = | type = [[Public company|Public]] | traded_as = {{NASDAQ|HMNY}} | industry = [[Data]]
[[Movie theater|Cinema]] | founded = {{Start date and age|1983}} | founder = | location = [[Empire State Building]] | location_city = [[Manhattan]], [[New York City]], [[New York (state)|New York]] | location_country = U.S. | area_served = | key_people = Ted Farnsworth
([[Chairman]] & [[Chief executive officer|CEO]]){{cite web|title=Our Team|publisher=Helios and Matheson Analytics|url=https://www.hmny.com/our-team/|accessdate=September 9, 2018}} | products = | net_income = {{loss}} [[United States dollar|US$]]150.8 million (2017) | owner = | num_employees = 71 (2018) | parent = | divisions = [[Moviefone]] | subsid = {{ubl|MoviePass, Inc.|[[MoviePass Films]]|Zone Technologies Inc.}} | website = {{URL|www.hmny.com}} }} Helios and Matheson Analytics is a publicly traded data analytics company based in [[New York City]], [[New York (state)|New York]] and is the parent company of MoviePass. The company was founded in 1983 by Shmuel BenTov as Software Ben-Tov.{{cite report|title=Form SB-2: Registration Statement|publisher=The A Consulting Team|date=June 13, 1997|pages=12 & 35|url=https://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/1040792/0000950130-97-002800.txt|via=EDGAR}} It changed its name later that year to The A Consulting Team. The company made its [[initial public offering]] in 1997.{{cite report|title=Form 10-KSB: Annual Report|publisher=The A Consulting Team|date=March 31, 1998|page=8|url=https://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/1040792/0001040792-98-000004.txt|via=EDGAR}} In 2006, Helios & Matheson Information Technology Ltd., an IT consulting firm based in India, purchased a majority stake in the company.{{cite news|title=Stock vindaloo: Shady Indian investors take grip of a U.S. firm|newspaper=New York Post|first=Christopher|last=Byron|date=August 7, 2006|url=https://infoweb.newsbank.com/resources/openurl?ctx_ver=z39.88-2004&rft_dat=document_id%3Anews%252F1135DC12AA891D48&rft_id=info%3Asid%2Finfoweb.newsbank.com&rft_val_format=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Actx&svc_dat=AWNB&req_dat=1028A39C75C2B899|via=NewsBank}}{{cite report|title=Form 8-K: Current Report|publisher=The A Consulting Team|date=September 8, 2006|url=https://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/1040792/000112528206005648/b414864_8k.txt|via=EDGAR}} The A Consulting Team changed its name in 2007 to Helios & Matheson North America, to highlight its association with the parent company.{{cite report|title=Form 10-K: Annual Report|publisher=Helios & Matheson North America|date=March 29, 2007|page=1|url=https://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/1040792/000095012307004660/y32542e10vk.htm|via=EDGAR}} The company again changed its name in 2011 to Helios & Matheson Information Technology Inc., to reflect that it was seeking business opportunities worldwide,{{cite report|title=Form 10-K: Annual Report|publisher=Helios & Matheson Information Technology|date=March 13, 2012|page=3|url=https://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/1040792/000114420412014589/v303156_10k.htm|via=EDGAR}} and then in 2013 to Helios and Matheson Analytics, to reflect that the business had "moved beyond IT".{{cite report|title=Form 10-K: Annual Report|publisher=Helios and Matheson Analytics|date=March 13, 2014|page=1|url=https://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/1040792/000143774914003183/hmny20131231_10k.htm|via=EDGAR}} The company acquired Zone Technologies, maker of the RedZone Map app, in November 2016.{{cite news |last1=Bary |first1=Emily |title=Helios & Matheson stock falls after company gets extension for 10-K filing |url=https://www.marketwatch.com/story/helios-matheson-stock-falls-after-company-gets-extension-for-10-k-filing-2018-04-03 |accessdate=June 5, 2018 |work=MarketWatch |date=April 3, 2018}}{{cite press release|title=Helios and Matheson Analytics and Zone Technologies, maker of RedZone Map, close merger|publisher=Helios and Matheson Analytics|date=November 9, 2016|url=https://infoweb.newsbank.com/resources/openurl?ctx_ver=z39.88-2004&rft_dat=document_id%3Anews%252F1608D06131CA5A68&rft_id=info%3Asid%2Finfoweb.newsbank.com&rft_val_format=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Actx&svc_dat=AWNB&req_dat=1028A39C75C2B899|via=NewsBank}} Zone founder Richard Farnsworth was appointed chairman of Helios, and then, in January 2017, became Helios's CEO.{{cite press release|title=Helios and Matheson Analytics Inc. names chairman Theodore Farnsworth as chief executive officer|publisher=Helios and Matheson Analytics|date=January 23, 2017|url=https://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/helios-and-matheson-analytics-inc-names-chairman-theodore-farnsworth-as-chief-executive-officer-300394541.html|accessdate=September 9, 2018}} In August 2017, Helios purchased a majority stake in MoviePass. Helios advanced MoviePass $55 million from December to February 20, 2018. MoviePass then converted the advances from debt to capital. This increased Helios' ownership stake from 62.4 percent to 81.2 percent. Another $35 million in advances converted to capital put Helios at 91.8 percent, allowing for a merger unilaterally initiated by the Helios board. In April 2018, Helios acquired the movie listings website [[Moviefone]] from [[Verizon]]'s digital media subsidiary, [[Oath Inc.]] As part of the transaction, Verizon took an equity stake in MoviePass. In March 2018, the board of directors began the process to spin off Zone Technologies to shareholders as a separate, publicly traded company, in hopes that it would allow Helios to focus on its strengths.{{cite press release|title=Helios and Matheson Analytics Inc. announces plans to spin-off Zone Technologies Inc. to become a separate public company|publisher=Helios and Matheson Analytics|date=March 15, 2018|url=https://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20180315005643/en/Helios-Matheson%C2%A0Analytics-Announces-Plans-Spin-Off-Zone-Technologies|accessdate=September 9, 2018}}{{cite news|title=MoviePass owner's shares tumble after stock-sale plan|newspaper=Wall Street Journal|first=Maria|last=Armental|date=April 18, 2018|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/moviepass-owners-shares-tumble-after-stock-sale-plan-1524110178|accessdate=September 9, 2018}} {{subscription required}} In April 2018, Helios sold $150 million in stock with $30 million of the shares at $2.75, a discount from the closing market price of $3.83. Most of the proceeds were used to fund MoviePass. With the diluting and discount on the shares, prior investors indicated their unhappiness with the company on Twitter.{{cite news |last1=Vega |first1=Nicolas |title=MoviePass faces angry investors after selling off $150M in stock |url=https://nypost.com/2018/04/19/moviepass-faces-angry-investors-after-selling-off-150m-in-stock/ |accessdate=June 5, 2018 |work=New York Post |date=April 20, 2018}} In May 2018, the company acquired the assets of [[Emmett Furla Oasis Films]] plus gain its executives' expertise in making films for a new subsidiary, [[MoviePass Films]] with an option to purchase the library.{{cite news |last1=Goldsmith |first1=Jill |title=MoviePass Expands And Will Now Make Movies Too |url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/jillgoldsmith/2018/05/31/moviepass-expands-and-will-now-make-movies-too/#a2686e7400ad |accessdate=October 16, 2018 |work=Forbes |date=May 31, 2018 |language=en}} The new company would be 51% owned by Helios and the remainder by EFO.{{cite news |last1=Lang |first1=Brent |title=MoviePass Parent Company Acquiring Emmett Furla Oasis Films |url=https://variety.com/2018/film/news/moviepass-emmett-furla-lone-survivor-1202825039/ |accessdate=June 4, 2018 |work=Variety |date=May 30, 2018}} By early August 2018, Helios and Matheson completed the acquisition of Emmett Furla Oasis Films assets for the MoviePass subsidiary, MoviePass Films. In August 2018, the company reported a loss of $100 million in the second quarter of 2018 with the company trading at an implied value of $30 million.{{cite news |last=Salinas |first=Sara |last2=Forkin |first2=Jim |url=https://www.cnbc.com/2018/10/17/new-york-ag-launches-probe-into-moviepass-parent-company-for-allegedly-misleading-investors-source.html |title=New York AG launches probe into MoviePass parent company for allegedly misleading investors |work=[[CNBC]] |date=2018-10-17 |accessdate=2018-10-19 }} In October of 2018, the [[Attorney General of New York]] opened an investigation into Helios and Matheson Analytics, looking into whether it misled investors about the company's financial situation. With market perception of MoviePass affecting Helios & Matheson's stock value, in October 2018 the company revealed a preliminary plan to spin off its film industry units as MoviePass Entertainment Holdings. The plan calls for a stock dividend of a minority of the holding company's stock allowing Helios to retain a controlling interest and for listing the new company on the NASDAQ or alternative market.{{cite news |last1=Vlessing |first1=Etan |title=MoviePass Parent to Spin Off Cinema Subscription Service |url=https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/moviepass-parent-confirms-ipo-plans-cinema-subscription-service-1154382 |accessdate=October 23, 2018 |work=The Hollywood Reporter |date=October 23, 2018 |language=en}} ==MoviePass Ventures== On January 19, 2018 at the [[Sundance Film Festival]], MoviePass announced the new subsidiary MoviePass Ventures, which would co-acquire films with traditional distributors. Lowe explained that the company wanted to "bring great films to the big screen across the country for our subscribers", and that "given the successes we have demonstrated for our distributor partners in ensuring strong box office in the theatrical window, it's only natural for us to double down and want to play alongside them – and share in the upside." MoviePass Ventures' first acquisition (in partnership with [[The Orchard (company)|The Orchard]]), Bart Layton's ''[[American Animals]]'', was on June 1, 2018, while their second, ''[[Gotti (2018 film)|Gotti]]'' starring John Travolta as the titular [[John Gotti|mob boss]], was released on June 15, 2018.{{Cite news|url=http://deadline.com/2018/02/moviepass-american-animals-the-orchard-1202288609/|title=The Orchard & MoviePass Ventures To Unleash Sundance Acquisition ‘American Animals’ This Summer|last=D'Alessandro|first=Anthony|date=February 14, 2018|website=Deadline Hollywood|access-date=February 14, 2018|language=en-US}} The MoviePass Venture operation was questioned by some in the industry, with one independent studio head telling ''[[Deadline Hollywood]]'': "It used to be in distribution, we'd all gossip whether a studio was buying tickets to their own movie to goose their opening, but in the case of MoviePass, there's no secret: They're literally buying the tickets to their own movie".{{cite web|url=https://deadline.com/2018/06/incredibles-2-tag-superfly-weekend-box-office-1202411262/|title='Incredibles 2' Opens To $18.5M In Thursday Previews|website=[[Deadline Hollywood]] |publisher=[[Penske Business Media]] |date=June 15, 2018 |first=Anthony |last= D'Alessandro |accessdate=June 15, 2018}} According to MoviePass' own reports, the service made up 25–35% of ''American Animals''{{'}} opening weekend ticket sales, and around 40% of ''Gotti''{{'}}s.{{cite web|url=https://deadline.com/2018/06/moviepass-gotti-opening-rotten-tomatoes-0-1202412227/|title=MoviePass Reps 40% Of ‘Gotti’s $1.67M Opening As Critics Slaughter John Travolta Mob Pic|website=[[Deadline Hollywood]] |publisher=[[Penske Business Media]] |date=June 17, 2018 |first=Anthony |last= D'Alessandro |accessdate=June 17, 2018}} ===MoviePass Venture films=== It was noted that the MoviePass Ventures film ''[[Gotti (2018 film)|Gotti]]'' had large disparities between critic and audience scores on [[Rotten Tomatoes]], with most of the positive reviews coming from new users, and those whose only other review was of fellow release ''[[American Animals]]''. This led to allegations that MoviePass was attempting to manipulate reviews in order to bolster the service.{{cite web |url=https://www.pastemagazine.com/articles/2018/06/something-suspicious-is-happening-with-rotten-toma.html |title=Something Suspicious Is Happening With Rotten Tomatoes User Reviews for Gotti |website=[[Paste (magazine)|Paste]] |access-date=June 20, 2018 |date=June 19, 2018 |first=Jim |last=Vorel |publisher=Paste Media Group}}{{cite web |url=http://ew.com/movies/2018/06/19/gotti-slams-movie-critics/ |title='Gotti' fires back at movie critics after terrible reviews: 'A troll behind a keyboard' |website=[[Entertainment Weekly]] |access-date=June 20, 2018 |first=James |last=Hibbard |date=June 19, 2018 |publisher=[[Time (magazine)|Time]]}} {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! Title ! Release date ! Production companies ! Distributor ! Notes |- | ''[[American Animals]]'' | June 1, 2018 | {{ubl|Film4|AI Film|Raw production}} | [[The Orchard (company)|The Orchard]] | |- |''[[Gotti (2018 film)|Gotti]]'' | June 15, 2018 | {{ubl|[[Emmett/Furla/Oasis Films|EFO Films]]|Highland Film Group|Fiore Films}} | [[Vertical Entertainment]]
Sunrider Productions | |- | ''The Row'' | 2018 | {{ubl|Grindstone Entertainment Group|Emmett Furla Oasis Films|The Fyzz Facility|Fuel 1}} | Lionsgate | July 27th, 2018{{cite web |title=The Row (2018) - Financial Information |url=https://www.the-numbers.com/movie/Row-The-(2018)#tab=summary |website=The Numbers |accessdate=October 16, 2018}}{{cite news |last1=Burke |first1=Carolyn |title=MoviePass Films Announces 10 Minutes Gone Starring Bruce Willis |url=https://screenrant.com/moviepass-films-bruce-willis-movie/ |accessdate=October 16, 2018 |work=ScreenRant |date=August 7, 2018}} |} == See also == * [[Sinemia]] ==References== {{reflist|colwidth=30em}} [[Category:2011 establishments in New York (state)]] [[Category:Companies based in New York City]] [[Category:Ticket sales companies]] [[Category:Film industry]] [[Category:Subscription services]]

revision.comment: /* top */Journal cites, Added 1 doi to a journal cite
revision.text:
'''Multiperspectivity''' (sometimes '''polyperspectivity''') is a characteristic of [[narration]] or [[Representation (arts)|representation]], where more than one perspective is represented to the audience.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://www.lhn.uni-hamburg.de/article/multiperspectivity|title=Multiperspectivity|last=Hartner|first=Marcus|date=|website=The Living Handbook of Narratology|publisher=University of Hamburg|access-date=2016-09-19}}</ref>
Most frequently the term is applied to [[fiction]] which employs '''multiple narrators''', often in opposition to each-other or to illuminate different elements of a plot,<ref name=":0" /> creating what is sometimes called a '''multiple narrative,'''<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://education.seattlepi.com/multiple-narrative-5829.html|title=What Is a Multiple Narrative?|last=Magher|first=Maria|date=|website=|publisher=|access-date=2016-09-19}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.euronet.nl/users/mcbeijer/dan/mns/|title=Multiple Narrative Structures in Contemporary Cinema|last=Hassler-Forest|first=Dan|date=|website=|publisher=|access-date=}}</ref> or '''multi-narrative'''.<ref>{{Cite journal|date=2014-02-02|title=Same Difference: Humanity as Allegory in the Multi-Narrative Film|url=http://film-philosophy.com/conference/index.php/conf/F-P2014/paper/viewPaper/907|language=en}}</ref>
However, a similar concept is applied to [[Historical method|historical process]], in which '''multiple different perspectives''' are used to evaluate events.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://teachinghistory.org/teaching-materials/ask-a-master-teacher/23610|title=Multiperspectivity: What Is It, and Why Use It? {{!}} Teachinghistory.org|website=teachinghistory.org|access-date=2016-09-19}}</ref> Educators have extended the concept and term to apply to techniques used to teach multiple disciplines, including [[Social science|social sciences]], like [[economics]] and [[civics]],<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Weber|first=Birgit|date=2016-02-26|title=Multiperspectivity, Values and Criticism in Economic and Civic Education|url=http://www.jsse.org/index.php/jsse/article/view/1510|journal=JSSE - Journal of Social Science Education|language=en|volume=14|issue=4|doi=10.2390/jsse-v14-i4-1510|issn=1618-5293}}</ref> and [[physical education]].<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Krüger|first=Arnd|date=2012-10-29|title=Multiperspectivity as a basis of current German physical education|url=http://www.cairn.info/resume.php?ID_ARTICLE=SM_078_0011|journal=Movement & Sport Sciences|language=en|issue=78|pages=11–23|issn=2118-5735|doi=10.1051/sm/2012020}}</ref>
== See also == * [[Mosaic novel]] - a genre of novel employing multiperspectivity
== References == {{Reflist}}{{Narrative}} [[Category:Narrative techniques]] [[Category:Point of view]] [[Category:Style (fiction)]]

{{Infobox Artwork | image_file=Sassetta 002.jpg | title=Mystic Marriage of St. Francis | artist=Sassetta | year= c. 1450 | medium=Tempera on panel | height_metric=95 | width_metric=58 | metric_unit=cm | imperial_unit=in | city=[[Chantilly, Oise|Chantilly]] | museum=[[Musée Condé]] }}
The '''''Mystic Marriage of St. Francis''''' is a painting by the Italian Renaissance artist [[Stefano di Giovanni|Sassetta]], currently housed in the [[Musée Condé]] of [[Chantilly, Oise|Chantilly]], [[France]].
==Description== The painting was originally part of a [[polyptych]] at [[Sansepolcro]], where it was seen by [[Piero della Francesca]].
It portrays [[St. Francis of Assisi]] while ideally marrying the three [[Theological Virtues]], Faith, Hope and Charity, through the donation of a ring to them. The three virtues have differently colored dresses: red for Charity, green for Hope and white for Faith; they are also depicted on the left while flying to heaven with sticks in their hands. Behind St. Francis, who wears his traditional brown monk habit, is his companion Fra' Leone.
The scene is set in an idyllic landscape, between hills, castles and cultivated fields, without any attention to perspective and realism as in other Renaissance works. Sassetta was in fact one of the last painters of the Sienese Gothic school, as shown by the use of elongated figures, the delicate colors and the courtly atmosphere.
== Sources== * {{cite book|first=Stefano|language=Italian|last= Zuffi|title=Il Quattrocento|location= Milan|publisher= Electa|year=2004}}
[[Category:1450s paintings]] [[Category:Paintings of the Musée Condé]] [[Category:Gothic paintings]] [[Category:Religious paintings]] [[Category:Paintings of Francis of Assisi]]

revision.comment: Fix [[:Category:CS1 maint: Extra text|CS1 cite error]] (extra text in "page" or "edition" parameter), and genfixes
revision.text:
'''Nancy Levinson''' is an editor and writer working at the intersection of journalism, scholarship, architecture, and urbanism.<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=https://muledesign.com/2017/07/goat-salon-q-a-with-nancy-levinson|title=GOAT Salon: Q&A with Nancy Levinson - Mule|website=Mule|language=en-US|access-date=2018-04-29}}</ref> She has been the editor and executive director of [https://placesjournal.org/ ''Places'' journal] since 2008''.'' She was the Founding Director of the Phoenix Urban Research Lab at The Design School at [[Arizona State University]], and a founding editor of ''[[Harvard Design Magazine]]'' at the [[Harvard Graduate School of Design]].
== Education == Levinson gained her BA from [[Yale University]] and her Master of Architecture from the [[University of Pennsylvania]].<ref name=":2">{{Cite news|url=https://placesjournal.org/author/nancy-levinson/|title=Nancy Levinson {{!}} Places Journal|work=Places Journal|access-date=2018-04-29|language=en-US}}</ref>
== Career == Levinson began her career with a short period in architectural practice before moving into architectural journalism. She has published in a wide range of media, both professional and scholarly, including the ''[[Journal of Planning Literature]], [[Yale Journal of Architecture]]'', ''[[I.D. (magazine)|I.D.]]'', ''Metropolis'', ''[[Landscape Architecture (magazine)|Landscape Architecture]]'', ''[[The Christian Science Monitor]]'', and ''[[Architectural Record]]'', for which she was a contributing editor.<ref name=":2" /><ref name="ArtsJournal: PIXEL POINTS">{{Cite web|url=http://artsjournal.com/pixelpoints/about/aboutnancy.shtml|title=ArtsJournal: PIXEL POINTS|website=artsjournal.com|access-date=2018-04-29}}</ref> She has also edited books for the [[Princeton Architectural Press]] and contributed chapters to ''Architecture and Film'', edited by Mark Lamster, and ''Judging Architectural Value''.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/42842390|title=Architecture and film|date=2000|publisher=Princeton Architectural Press|others=Lamster, Mark, 1969-|isbn=1568982070|edition= 1st|location=New York|oclc=42842390}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.papress.com/html/product.details.dna?isbn=9781568982076|title=Architecture and Film|website=www.papress.com|access-date=2018-04-29}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.upress.umn.edu/book-division/books/judging-architectural-value|title=Judging Architectural Value|website=University of Minnesota Press|language=en|access-date=2018-04-29}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/71833337|title=Judging architectural value|date=2007|publisher=University of Minnesota Press|others=Saunders, William S.|isbn=9780816650101|location=Minneapolis, MN|oclc=71833337}}</ref> Levinson also spent a period as ‘editor in the archives’ at the [[Canadian Centre for Architecture]].<ref name=":2" />
In 1997 Levinson co-founded ''[[Harvard Design Magazine]]'', the biannual publication of the [[Harvard Graduate School of Design|Harvard University Graduate School of Design]], with William Saunders, and continued co-editing the publication until 2001. Issues she directed and edited addressed a wide range of topics, including metropolitan form, monuments, spectacle culture, and post-communist Eastern Europe.<ref name=":3">{{Cite web|url=http://www.grahamfoundation.org/grantees/5071-history-of-the-present-cities-in-transition|title=Graham Foundation > Grantees > Places Journal|website=www.grahamfoundation.org|access-date=2018-04-29}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.harvarddesignmagazine.org/issues/9|title=Harvard Design Magazine: No. 9 / Constructions of Memory: On Monuments Old and New|website=www.harvarddesignmagazine.org|access-date=2018-04-29}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.harvarddesignmagazine.org/issues/13|title=Harvard Design Magazine: No. 13 / East of Berlin: Postcommunist Cities Now|website=www.harvarddesignmagazine.org|access-date=2018-04-29}}</ref> From September 2004 until November 2006 Levinson wrote [http://www.artsjournal.com/pixelpoints/ Pixel Points] for the [[Art Journal (College Art Association journal)|''Arts Journal'']], an early manifestation of architectural blogging.<ref name="ArtsJournal: PIXEL POINTS"/>
Levinson became the founding director of the [http://purl-asu.tumblr.com/ Phoenix Urban Research Lab] and Professor of Practice at the Design School at [[Arizona State University]] in 2007.<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=https://asunow.asu.edu/content/purl-director-named-editor-places|title=PURL director named editor of 'Places'|date=2008-11-07|work=ASU Now: Access, Excellence, Impact|access-date=2018-04-29|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://purl-asu.tumblr.com/|title=The Phoenix Urban Research Lab|website=purl-asu.tumblr.com|access-date=2018-04-29}}</ref> She was appointed editor of ''Places Journal'' in 2008, replacing long-time editor [[Donlyn Lyndon]], and maintained both roles until she was appointed full-time at ''Places''.<ref name=":0" />
Levinson also contributes to architectural culture as a design juror and public speaker.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://umanitoba.ca/faculties/architecture/atmosphere/2015/levinson.html|title=Levinson {{!}} Atmos 2015 Emergence|website=umanitoba.ca|language=en-US|access-date=2018-04-29}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://terrain.design.upenn.edu/speakers/nancy-levinson.html|title=in the terrain of water {{!}} Penn Design • NANCY LEVINSON|website=terrain.design.upenn.edu|access-date=2018-04-29}}</ref>
== Editorial practice == Levinson focuses on the opportunities presented by digital and online media for reaching new audiences and expanding the impact of scholarly work.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Levinson|first=Nancy|date=2013-10-01|title=Print and Pixel|url=https://placesjournal.org/article/print-and-pixel/|journal=Places Journal|language=en-US|issue=2013|doi=10.22269/131001|issn=2164-7798}}</ref><ref name=":1" /> Under Levinson’s editorship, ''Places'' moved from print to online and built a substantial and wide-ranging interdisciplinary readership.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://placesjournal.org/news/from-the-editor-2009/|title=From the Editor|work=Places Journal|access-date=2018-04-29|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://landscapearchitecturemagazine.org/2014/10/22/places-journal-has-a-new-place/|title=PLACES JOURNAL HAS A NEW PLACE|date=2014-10-22|work=Landscape Architecture Magazine|access-date=2018-04-29|language=en-US}}</ref> Levinson has expanded the mandate of the journal under the tagline “Public scholarship on architecture, landscape, and urbanism”''.''<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://placesjournal.org/|title=Places Journal|work=Places Journal|access-date=2018-04-29|language=en-US}}</ref> Her editorial direction is described as “harnessing the moral and investigative power of public scholarship to promote equitable cities and sustainable landscapes.”<ref name=":3" />
Levinson has led funding campaigns to support the research and publication on topics that might not otherwise be addressed. This has resulted in funding from the [[Graham Foundation for Advanced Studies in the Fine Arts|Graham Foundation]] for three initiatives – History of the Present: Cities in Transition,<ref name=":3" /> Future Archive<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.grahamfoundation.org/grantees/5232-future-archive|title=Graham Foundation > Grantees > Places Journal|website=www.grahamfoundation.org|access-date=2018-04-29}}</ref> and the Writers’ Fund.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.grahamfoundation.org/grantees/5526-places-journal-writers-fund|title=Graham Foundation > Grantees > Places Journal|website=www.grahamfoundation.org|access-date=2018-04-29}}</ref> The Inequality Chronicles, a series investigating racial, social and economic inequality in American cities, was funded by [[The Kresge Foundation]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://placesjournal.org/series/the-inequality-chronicles/|title=The Inequality Chronicles: A Series on Places Journal|work=Places Journal|access-date=2018-05-01|language=en-US}}</ref>
Levinson has also used ''Places'' as a foundation on which to build a range of related enterprises that seek to expand participation, readership and the dissemination of scholarship on the built environment. Initiatives include [https://press.princeton.edu/catalogs/series/title/places-books.html Places Books], a collaboration between Places and [[Princeton Architectural Press]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://press.princeton.edu/catalogs/series/title/places-books.html|title=Browse Princeton Catalog in Places Books {{!}} Princeton University Press|website=press.princeton.edu|language=en|access-date=2018-04-29}}</ref> The first in the series is ''Where are the Women Architects?'' by [[Despina Stratigakos]], which has been well received across academia and the architectural profession.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/935925102|title=Where are the women architects?|last=Despina,|first=Stratigakos,|isbn=9781400880294|location=Princeton|oclc=935925102}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.timeshighereducation.com/books/review-where-are-the-women-architects-despina-stratigakos-princeton-university-press|title=Where are the Women Architects?, by Despina Stratigakos|last=Samuel|first=Flora|authorlink=Flora Samuel|date=June 2, 2016|website=Times Higher Education|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://archiparlour.org/where-are-the-women-architects/|title=Where are the Women Architects|last=Thompson|first=Kerstin|authorlink=Kerstin Thompson|date=October 10, 2016|website=Parlour: women, equity, architecture|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://spacing.ca/national/2017/01/24/book-review-where-are-the-women-architects/|title=Book Review: Where Are the Women Architects? - Spacing National|date=2017-01-24|work=Spacing National|access-date=2018-04-29|language=en-US}}</ref> The [https://placesjournal.org/reading-lists/ Places Reading List] is a collaborative tool that allows readers to share knowledge and generate content.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://placesjournal.org/news/places-journal-launches-new-tool-for-interdisciplinary-public-scholarship/|title=Places Journal launches new tool for interdisciplinary public scholarship|work=Places Journal|access-date=2018-04-29|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.archdaily.com/609192/places-journal-launches-new-tool-for-sharing-articles-about-architecture-landscape-and-urbanism|title=Places Journal Launches New Tool for Sharing Articles about Architecture, Landscape, and Urbanism|date=2015-03-13|work=ArchDaily|access-date=2018-04-29|language=en-US}}</ref>
== References == {{Reflist}}

page.title: Neighborhood Playhouse School of the Theatre

revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=November 2015}} {{coord|40|45|24|N|73|57|55|W|region:US-NY_type:landmark_source:kolossus-dewiki|display=title}} {{Infobox organization |name = The Neighborhood Playhouse School of the Theatre |image = I Neighborhood Playhouse, NYC, NY.jpg |image_size = 287px |caption = |leader_title = |leader_name = |leader_title2 = |leader_name2 = |membership = |headquarters = 340 [[54th Street (Manhattan)|East 54th Street]]
[[New York City]] |formation = 1928 |type = Drama school |predecessor = |budget= |purpose= |region_served = United States |num_staff = |num_volunteers = |motto = |website = {{url|neighborhoodplayhouse.org}} }} The '''Neighborhood Playhouse School of the Theatre''' is a full-time [[Drama school|professional conservatory for actors]] located at 340 East 54th Street in New York City, and is known as the home of the [[Meisner technique]], developed by [[Sanford Meisner]]. ==History== [[File:Neighborhood Playhouse School of the Theatre building on Grand Street in 1916.jpg|left|thumb|275px|The Grand Street building in 1916]] The '''Neighborhood Playhouse''' had originally been founded as an [[off-Broadway]] theatre by philanthropists [[Alice Lewisohn]] and [[Irene Lewisohn]] in 1915, but closed in 1927. The following year, it re-opened as The Neighborhood Playhouse School of the Theatre with the addition of Rita Wallach Morgenthau. [[Sanford Meisner]] joined the faculty in 1935 from the [[Group Theatre (New York)|Group Theatre]]. Meisner used his study of Russian theatre and acting innovator, [[Konstantin Stanislavski]]'s [[Stanislavski System|System]] to develop his own technique, as an alternative to [[Lee Strasberg]]'s [[Method acting]]. The Executive Director Emeritus of the Playhouse, Harold G. Baldridge, a graduate of the school himself, had been head of the school for 32 years. Pamela Moller Kareman serves as the current Executive Director, also a graduate of The Neighborhood Playhouse School of the Theatre. The school offers a Two Year Certificate Program, with admission to the second year dependent upon unanimous approval of the faculty. There is also a Six Week Summer Intensive. The Neighborhood Playhouse also offers Playhouse Juniors, a popular Saturday training program for children in grades 1–12. Children attend a fixed curriculum of singing, acting and dancing classes in a non-competitive environment. Playwright [[Horton Foote]] met actor [[Robert Duvall]] at Neighborhood Playhouse when Duvall starred in a 1957 production of Foote's play, ''[[The Midnight Caller (play)|The Midnight Caller]]''. Foote recommended Duvall to play the part of [[List of To Kill a Mockingbird characters#Arthur .22Boo.22 Radley|Boo Radley]] in the 1962 film, ''[[To Kill a Mockingbird (film)|To Kill a Mockingbird]]''.{{cite video|people= [[Robert Duvall]] (actor), Gary Hertz (director) |date= April 16, 2002 |title = Miracles & Mercies |url= https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0383509/ |medium= Documentary |publisher= [[Blue Underground]] |location= [[West Hollywood]], California |accessdate = 2008-01-28}}{{clear left}} ==Alumni== {{div col|colwidth=30em}} * [[R.J. {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2011}} '''Nesting Orientalisms''' is a concept introduced by Milica Bakić-Hayden, a [[visiting lecturer]] at the [[University of Pittsburgh]]. It is based on gradation of "Orients", i.e. otherness and primitiveness.
== Background == As developed by Milica Bakić-Hayden, '''Nesting Orientalisms''' is a conceptual variant of [[Edward Said]]'s theory of [[Orientalism (book)|Orientalism]]; an additional influence is [[Larry Wolff]],<ref>{{Citation |last=Ashbrook |first=John E |editor= |editorn= |editorn-last= |editorn-first= |editor-link= |editorn-link= |others= |title=Buying and selling the Istrian goat : Istrian regionalism, Croatian nationalism, and EU enlargement |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=uk9VVZ1esGwC&pg=PA22&dq=%22Nesting+Orientalisms%22&hl=en&ei=GuBcTr_SG86N-wbg94HuAQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=3&ved=0CDUQ6AEwAg#v=onepage&q=%22Nesting%20Orientalisms%22&f=false |accessdate= |edition= |series= |origyear= |year=2008 |publisher=Peter Lang |location=New York |isbn=90-5201-391-8 |oclc=213599021 |doi-inactive-date=|bibcode= |id= |page=22 |nopp= |at= |chapter= |chapterurl= |quote=Milica Bakić-Hayden built on Wolff's work, incorporating ideas from Edward Said's ''Orientalism'' |laysummary= |laydate= |postscript= |lastauthoramp= |ref= }}</ref> but, in fact, she already had used the term ‘Nesting Orientalism’ in the article ‘Orientalist Variations on the Theme “Balkans”: Symbolic Geography in Recent Yugoslav Cultural Politics” (1992), co-author Robert Hayden, before Wolff published ''Inventing Eastern Europe''.<ref>Milica Bakic-Hayden and Robert Hayden, "Orientalist Variations on the Theme "Balkans": Symbolic Geography in Recent Yugoslav Cultural Politics" Slavic review, vol. 51, no. 1 (Spring 1992), p. 4.</ref>
== The concept ==
This concept explains "a tendency of each region to view the cultures and religions to its South and East as more conservative and primitive".<ref name="Petrović 2009 141">{{cite book|last=Petrović|first=Tanja|title=Kulturen der Differenz – Transformationsprozesse in Zentraleuropa nach 1989 transdisziplinäre Perspektiven|year=2009|publisher=Vienna Univ. Press|isbn=3-89971-714-7|editor=Heinz Fassmann|page=141}}</ref> It explains how a group which creates the Orientalized other can also be the subject of Orientalization by another group, and so on.<ref>{{Citation|last=Cela|first=Alba|title=‘Orientalism’ in service of Contemporary National Identity Building in Albania: The literary work of Ismail Kadare.|url=http://web.ceu.hu/nation/theses/Cela.pdf|accessdate=|edition=|series=|origyear=|year=2006|publisher=Central European University Nationalism Studies Program|location=Budapest, Hungary|isbn=|oclc=|doi-inactive-date=|bibcode=|id=|page=18|nopp=|at=|chapter=|chapterurl=|quote=Milica Bakic-Hayden’s work on “Nesting Orientalisms”... exposed how the project of creating a necessary other sometimes involves the Orientalization of one group by another, who has been in turn Orientalized by another, and so on.|laysummary=|laydate=|postscript=|lastauthoramp=|ref=|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111003122409/http://web.ceu.hu/nation/theses/Cela.pdf|archivedate=3 October 2011|df=dmy-all}}</ref> According to this concept Asia is more "east" or "other" than Eastern Europe. Within Eastern Europe the [[Balkans]] is perceived as most "eastern". Such hierarchy continues within the Balkans.<ref>{{Citation |last=Harrington |first=Carol |author2=Ayman Salem |author3=Tamara Zurabishvili |title=After communism : critical perspectives on society and sociology |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=fNejIRHgCyIC&pg=PA84&dq=%22Nesting+Orientalisms%22&hl=en&ei=GuBcTr_SG86N-wbg94HuAQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=2&ved=0CC4Q6AEwAQ#v=onepage&q=%22Nesting%20Orientalisms%22&f=false |accessdate= |edition= |series= |origyear= |location= |isbn=978-0-8204-6951-5 |oclc=56334118 |doi-inactive-date=|bibcode= |id= |page=84 |quote=...Hayden very interestingly introduced the idea of 'nesting Orientalism', which contains the process of descending East/West exclusion: "The gradation of 'Orients' that I call 'nesting Orientalisms' is a pattern of reproduction of the original dichotomy upon which the Orientalism is premised. }}</ref>
=== Nesting Balkanisms === In the case of the Balkans there are many rankings connected with this concept, which "play a significant role in . . . [[Identity (social science)|identity]] building [and proclaiming] a more prestigious position within a generally negatively assessed entity".<ref name=Ethnologia37>{{Citation |last=Elchinova |first= Magdalena |editor= |editorn= |editorn-last= |editorn-first= |editor-link= |editorn-link= |others= |title=Bulgaria's Way to Europe: Some Aspects of Identity Construction Among Bulgarian Students Today |url= https://books.google.com/books?id=0ogSzrXJEfMC&pg=PA37&dq=%22Nesting+Orientalisms%22&hl=en&ei=UUddToTxDOSk4AT93pUm&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=3&ved=0CDQQ6AEwAjgK#v=onepage&q=%22Nesting%20Orientalisms%22&f=false |accessdate= |edition= |series=Ethnologia Balkanica |volume=8 |origyear= |year= 2004 |publisher=Prof. M. Drinov Academic Pub. House |location= Sofia |isbn= |oclc=41714232 |doi-inactive-date=|bibcode= |id= |page=37 |nopp= |at= |chapter= |chapterurl= |quote=[C]f. the idea of 'nesting orientalisms' in Bakic-Hayden 1995, and the related concept of 'nesting balkanisms' in Todorova 1997 ... The dynamic nature of 'Europe' and 'the Balkans' is even more salient when the two are regarded as identity constructions. As such, they are still opposed to each other (Todorova 1997:19) for the Balkans are not alien to Europe, they are its 'darker side'|laysummary= |laydate= |postscript= |lastauthoramp= |ref= }}</ref> Proclaiming one's European character was a tool in creating the pattern of "nesting orientalisms" in the Balkans.<ref>{{Citation |last= Biehl |first= Peter F. |editor= |editorn= |editorn-last= |editorn-first= |editor-link= |editorn-link= |others= |title=Archäologien Europas: Geschichte, Methoden und Theorien |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Iqewqjc22igC&pg=PA316&dq=%22Nesting+Orientalisms%22&hl=en&ei=pVldTqCkIPT04QTKmaEd&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CCgQ6AEwADgo#v=onepage&q=%22Nesting%20Orientalisms%22&f=false |accessdate= |edition= |series= |origyear= |publisher=Waxmann |isbn=978-3-8309-1067-1 |oclc= |doi-inactive-date=|bibcode= |id= |page=316 |nopp= |at= |chapter= |chapterurl= |quote=The renegotiation of the European character of the Balkan peoples was the major issue among the conflicting parties, and a device in constructing the pattern of 'nesting orientalisms' mentioned above (Bakić-Hayden...) |laysummary= |laydate= |postscript= |lastauthoramp= |ref= }}</ref>
Hence, Bulgarian historian [[Maria Todorova]] introduced the related concept of "nesting balkanisms".<ref name=Ethnologia37/> Todorova emphasized the importance of this concept in identity constructions, which in the case of the Balkans involve the dual perception of the Balkans as a part of Europe but also as in opposition, as the "darker side" of Europe.<ref name=Ethnologia37/>
=== Nesting Colonialisms ===
Another concept related to the concept of nesting orientalisms was introduced by Tanja Petrović, a [[Serbs|Serbian]] [[Anthropology|anthropologist]] from [[Slovenia]]: that of "nesting colonialisms", which is marked by parallels and analogies of the [[European Union]] and the rest of the world, which are perceived as former colonial powers and former colonies. This concept provides members of European Union, no matter whether they had a colonial past or not, with a "pool" of discursive patterns used for exclusion of those who are outside the European Union.<ref name="Petrović 2009 141"/>
=== Nesting Occidentalisms ===
Bulgarian intellectuals have modified the concept of Nesting Orientalisms into the reversed concept of ''Nesting Occidentalisms''.<ref>{{cite book|last=Bracewell|first=Wendy|title=Balkan Departures: Travel Writing from South-Eastern Europe|year=2009|publisher=Berghahn|location=New York|isbn=1-84545-254-2|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=dCb4_3H6yjkC&pg=PA111&lpg=PA111&dq=%22nesting+occidentalisms%22&source=bl&ots=ysRGvoXMRf&sig=Ee2z3xuTCstOBgAWDvkGnAl9eSk&hl=en&ei=KixeTrDaLsbb4QSL2Jke&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CBcQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=%22nesting%20occidentalisms%22&f=false|author2=Alex Drace-Francis|accessdate=31 August 2011|page=111|quote=Milica Bakić Hayden speaks of "nesting Orientalisms". Bulgarian intellectuals ... appear to have ... adopted a reversed version of her model. They approach Europe in terms of 'nesting Occidentalisms' or a 'gradation of Occidents'. }}</ref>
The concept of nesting occidentalisms is present in the 2006 [[mockumentary]] ''[[Borat]]'', which exploits foreign and domestic hierarchies of [[Americans]].<ref>{{Citation|last=Hall|first=Richard Andrew|editor=|editorn=|editorn-last=|editorn-first=|editor-link=|editorn-link=|others=|title=BORAT: ORIENTALIST SATIRE FOR MAKE GLORIOUS DEBATE WESTERN INTELLIGENTSIYA|url=http://homepage.mac.com/khallbobo/RichardHall/pubs/boratslavicreview022807.pdf|accessdate=|edition=|series=|origyear=|location=|isbn=|oclc=|doi-inactive-date=|bibcode=|id=|nopp=|at=|chapter=|chapterurl=|quote=Borat! is replete with what might be called 'nesting occidentalisms' or 'nesting antiAmericanisms': that is, it creates and plays on foreign and domestic hierarchies of Americans, good, bad, and ugly|laysummary=|laydate=|postscript=|lastauthoramp=|ref=|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120305073153/http://homepage.mac.com/khallbobo/RichardHall/pubs/boratslavicreview022807.pdf|archivedate=5 March 2012|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
== See also ==

|chapterurl= |quote= |laysummary= |laydate= |postscript= |lastauthoramp= |ref= }} * {{Citation |last=Wolff |first=Larry |editor= |editorn= |editorn-last= |editorn-first= |editor-link= |editorn-link= |others= |title=Inventing Eastern Europe : the map of civilization on the mind of the enlightenment |url= |accessdate= |edition= |series= |origyear= |year=1994 |publisher=Stanford University Press |location=Stanford, Calif. |isbn=978-0-8047-2314-5 |oclc=298105078 |doi-inactive-date=|bibcode= |id= |nopp= |at= |chapter= |chapterurl= |quote= |laysummary= |laydate= |postscript= |lastauthoramp= |ref= }} * {{Citation |last= Bakić-Hayden |first=Milica |editor= |editorn= |editorn-last= |editorn-first= |editor-link= |editorn-link= |others= |title=Nesting Orientalisms: The Case of Former Yugoslavia |url= |accessdate= |edition= |series= |volume=54/4 |origyear= |year=1995 |publisher=Slavic Review|isbn= |oclc=479320036 |doi-inactive-date=|bibcode= |id= |pages= 917–931 |nopp= |at= |chapter= |chapterurl= |quote= |laysummary= |laydate= |postscript= |lastauthoramp= |ref= }} * {{Citation |last= Todorova |first= Maria |authorlink=Maria Todorova |editor= |editorn= |editorn-last= |editorn-first= |editor-link= |editorn-link= |others= |title=Imagining the Balkans |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=WZweAIJI0ZwC&dq=%22Imagining+the+Balkans%22&hl=en&src=bmrr&ei=JPBdTriQC-Xm4QSWv_BI&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CCkQ6AEwAA |accessdate= |edition= |series= |origyear= |year=1997 |publisher=Oxford University Press |location= New York |isbn= 978-9989-851-31-5 |oclc= 34282740 |doi-inactive-date=|bibcode= |id= |nopp= |at= |chapter= |chapterurl= |quote= |laysummary= |laydate= |postscript= |lastauthoramp= |ref= }} * "Nesting Balkanisms among Dalmatian and Istrian Croats in the 1990s" at the Special Convention "Nationalism, Identity and Regional Cooperation: Compatibilities and Incompatibilities" Centro per l'Europa centro orientale e balcanica in association with ASN Bologna University Forli, Italy (4–9 June 2002) * {{Citation |last= Petrović |first= Tanja |editor= |editorn= |editorn-last= |editorn-first= |editor-link= |editorn-link= |others= |title= 'Nesting colonialisms' : new and old patterns of exclusion in the European periphery |url= |accessdate= |edition= |series= |origyear= |publisher=Mirovni inštitut |location= Ljubljana |isbn= |oclc=443779356 |doi-inactive-date=|bibcode= |id= |page= 28 |nopp= |at= |chapter= |chapterurl= |quote= |laysummary= |laydate= |postscript= |lastauthoramp= |ref= }} * {{Citation |last= Petrović |first= Tanja|editor= |editorn= |editorn-last= |editorn-first= |editor-link= |editorn-link= |others= |title=Nesting Colonialisms: Austria, Slovenia and Discourses on the Western Balkans in the Context of the EU Enlargement |url=http://www.drzavljanska-vzgoja.org/Portals/0/Dokumenti/clanki/Petrovic_DMG_2.pdf |accessdate= |edition= |series= |origyear= |publisher=Znanstvenoraziskovalni center SAZU |location= Ljubljana
